description: From Middle English tynkere, perhaps from Old English *tincere, from tin (“tin”) + Old English *cere (as in bēocere (“beekeeper”)), from Proto-West Germanic *kaʀi, from Proto-Germanic *kazjaz (“vessel-maker”), from Proto-Germanic *kazą (“vessel; vat; tub”).

entries.meaning: An itinerant tinsmith and mender of household utensils made of metal.
(dated, chiefly Britain and Ireland, offensive) A member of the Irish Traveller community or of other itinerant groups. A gypsy.
(usually with "little") A mischievous person, especially a playful, impish youngster.
Someone who repairs, or attempts repair, on anything mechanical, or who invents such devices; one who tinkers; a tinkerer.
The act of repair or invention.
Any of various fish: chub mackerel, silverside, skate, or young mackerel about two years old.

verbs.description: tinker (third-person singular simple present tinkers, present participle tinkering, simple past and past participle tinkered)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To fiddle with something in an attempt to fix, mend or improve it, especially in an experimental or unskilled manner.
examples: the broken bureau-lock and tinkered window-pane
